subject.name: Engineering Physics
subject.description: A foundational course introducing core principles of physics relevant to engineering, including mechanics, optics, quantum physics, electromagnetism, and materials science.
objectives: Understand the fundamental concepts of physics applied in engineering systems.
Develop problem-solving ability in optics, electromagnetism, and quantum mechanics.
Establish conceptual and mathematical understanding of physical principles underlying technology.

units.title: Frame of Reference and Oscillations
topics: Non-inertial frame of reference, rotating coordinate system, centripetal and Coriolis acceleration, and their applications in weather systems.
Harmonic oscillator, damped harmonic motion – overdamped, critically damped, and lightly damped oscillators; force oscillators and resonance.

units.title: Optics and Lasers
topics: Huygens’s principle, superposition of waves, and interference of light by wavefront splitting and amplitude-splitting.
Young’s double-slit experiment, Michelson interferometer, Fraunhofer diffraction from single slit and circular aperture, diffraction grating, and resolving power.

Einstein’s theory of matter–radiation interaction, Einstein’s coefficients (A and B), amplification by population inversion; types of lasers – gas laser, helium–neon laser, solid-state laser (ruby, neodymium), and semiconductor laser.

units.title: Quantum Mechanics and Applications
topics: Compton effect, photoelectric effect, wave–particle duality, de Broglie’s hypothesis, Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle.
Wave function and wave packets, phase and group velocities, Schrödinger’s wave equation, normalization, expectation values, eigenvalues, and eigenfunctions.
Application of Schrödinger’s wave equation for a particle in a one-dimensional box – wave function and eigenvalues of energy and momentum.

units.title: Vector Calculus and Electrostatics
topics: Gradient, divergence, and curl; line, surface, and volume integrals; Gauss’s divergence theorem and Stokes’ theorem in Cartesian coordinates.

Gauss’s law and its applications; divergence and curl of electrostatic fields; electrostatic potential; boundary conditions; Poisson’s and Laplace’s equations; dielectrics, polarization, bound charges, electric displacement, and boundary conditions in dielectrics.

units.title: Magnetostatics and Electrodynamics
topics: Lorentz force, Biot–Savart and Ampere’s circuital laws and their applications; divergence and curl of magnetostatic fields; magnetic vector potential; force and torque on a magnetic dipole; magnetic materials, magnetization, bound currents, and boundary conditions.

Ohm’s law, motional EMF, Faraday’s law, Lenz’s law; self and mutual inductance; energy stored in magnetic fields; Maxwell’s equations in vacuum and nonconducting media; continuity equation, Poynting theorem, and wave equations for plane electromagnetic waves in vacuum — their transverse nature and polarization.

units.title: Solid-State Physics and Electronic Materials
topics: Free electron theory of metals, Fermi level, Bloch’s theorem for particles in a periodic potential, Kronig–Penney model, and origin of energy bands.
Metals, semiconductors, and insulators; intrinsic and extrinsic semiconductors; carrier transport, diffusion, and drift; P–N junction.
